New York University Archives
Records of the Research Institute for the Study of Man's (RISM) Medical and Social Anthropological Research in Bolivia
Research Institute for the Study of Man
RISM RG 8
142.5 Linear Feet in 378 boxes
1964-1997 1964-1967 The RISM Bolivia Project was initiated in 1964 at the request of the U.S. Peace Corps. Headed by Dr. Vera D. Rubin, founder and director of RISM, and Dr. Lambros Comitas, assistant director of RISM, anthropological and epidemiological teams studied six ecologically distinct communities in order to identify major health problems and to assess the implications of rural social organization to facilitate the work of development agencies. The Bolivia Project generated thousands of documents, including correspondence, accounting records, indexed field notes, laboratory processing records, surveys and questionnaires, epidemiological data, maps, photographs, microfiche and microfilm. The collection also includes appended items from an exhibition, Retrospect and Prospect: Preservation and Use of Archival Materials in the Digital Age, which celebrated the Bolivia Project. Appended items include exhibit brochures, information panels, oversized computer generated charts, and video tapes. Materials are in English and Spanish. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact university-archives@nyu.edu at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions unless otherwise noted.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
The materials associated with the Bolivia Project were created by teams of epidemiological and ethnographic researchers between 1964 - 1967 and transferred to the New York University Archives in 2006. In 2017 an accretion of correspondence was transferred to the archives by the Reed Foundation; the accession number associated with this gift is 2017.020.

Appendix: Reports from RISM to the Peace Corps, Partial Reports Related to the RISM Bolivia Project, 1964-1967
Historical Note
In 1964, an intensive three-year medical-anthropological research program in Bolivia was undertaken by RISM at the request of the United States Peace Corps and in cooperation with the Bolivian Ministry of Public Health. The program was conducted under contract with the United States Peace Corps and received significant supplementary support from RISM. The goal of the research was to provide basic information for the development of public health and sanitation programs. Project administration was carried out by RISM director Vera D. Rubin and associate director Lambros Comitas, along with William J. McEwen who served as the project research director and Abdel Omran, who was director of the epidemiological research.
The project had two interrelated research objectives: The epidemiological team attempted to define the major problems of health and disease in rural Bolivian communities, taking into account the drastically different ecological regions of the country. The communities surveyed included Villa Abecia, Coroico, Reyes and Sorata, Compi and San Miguel. Clinical studies were conducted on a sample of 3,000 subjects to determine the incidence of tuberculosis and parasitic infections, the major endemic diseases affecting the region, and of nutritional and health status. Simultaneously, the ethnographic team conducted community studies in the same areas to provide background data on social and cultural features with special regard to attitudes toward health and disease and the structure of local institutions in the rural communities.
Over eighty medical and social scientists, field workers, nurses, data analysts, and staff in the United States and Bolivia contributed to the project. Quarterly reports describing the work and the course of research were filed with the Peace Corps. Results and analysis were published in two companion volumes: the epidemiological report was published by RISM in 1967, and the ethnographic report was published by RISM in 1969 and in 1971 by Oxford University Press. In addition, a number of articles, reports, theses and doctoral dissertations resulted from the project research.
References
Omran, Abdel R., William J. McEwen, and Mahfouz H. Zaki. Epidemiological Studies in Bolivia: Final Epidemiological Report for the Peace Corps. New York: Research Institute for the Study of Man, 1967. (Spanish trans. Estudios Epidemiologicos en Bolivia)
McEwen, William J. Changing Rural Bolivia: Final Anthropological Report for the Peace Corps. New York: Research Institute for the Study of Man, 1969.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date(s); Records of the Research Institute for the Study of Man's (RISM) Medical and Social Anthropological Research in Bolivia; RISM RG 8; box number; folder number; Research Institute for the Study of Man/New York University Archives; New York University.
Processing Information
Information about decisions concerning the arrangement, description, or physical interventions taken on this collection prior to 2017 have not yet been recorded. In 2017 an accretion of correspondence was incorporated into Series I. Correspondence based on the collection's existing arrangement structure; at this point the descriptive front matter of the collection as also revised. In 2019, materials were rehoused by Preservation and sent to offsite storage.
Scope and Contents
The Bolivia Project (1964-1967) consists of 200 linear feet of materials, including correspondence, accounting records, biographical index cards, indexed field notes, epidemiological and ethnographic studies and reports, laboratory processing records and results, blood typing cards, health questionnaires, computer generated charts, questionnaires and surveys that focus on household sanitation data and investigation of infant feeding habits, community censuses, maps, oversized charts, microfiche, microfilm, articles, unpublished manuscripts and accounting records, photographs, and videotapes. Material from a 1997 exhibit, Retrospect and Prospect: Preservation and Use of Archival Materials in the Digital Age, has also been appended to the collection.
Conditions Governing Use
This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

Series I. Correspondence
Scope and Contents
This series consists of 5.5 linear feet of both incoming and outgoing correspondence relating to various phases of the project, arranged alphabetically by the correspondents' last names or subject matter. Accounting Records
Scope and Contents note
These materials (Boxes 12-15) remain at the Reed Foundation. Please contact the Foundation for access to this series.Series III. Indexes
Scope and Contents
This series consists of index cards that serve as a quick reference to the original field notes. The cards have been organized into four subseries.Subseries A. Biographical Index Cards
Scope and Contents
This subseries contains approximately 5,300 biographical index cards compiled during the processing of ethnographic research materials. These cards do not include names, Community Househould Numbers, or Member of the Household Numbers. The index cards, organized by community, include an alphabetical arrangement of inteviewees, the initials of individual field workers, and page numbers from the original field notes.Compi Biographical Index Cards A - Zundated16Coroico Biographical Index Cards A - Zundated17Reyes Biographical Index Cards A - Zundated18San Miguel Biographical Index Cards A - Zundated19Sorata Biographical Index Cards A - Zundated20Villa Abecia Biographical Index Cards A - Mundated21Villa Abecia Biographical Index Cards N - Zundated22Subseries B. CSO Indexed Field Notes Cards
Scope and Contents
This subseries contains approximately 86,000 Community Study Outline (CSO) indexed field notecards. The cards are organized by community. The CSO index number is noted next to a bracket on the left side of each card, as are the initials of the field worker and the page of the original field notes.Coroico (CSO index 1 - 733)undated232425262728293031323334353637383940414243444546474849505152535455565758596061626364656667Reyes (CSO index 1 - 733)undated6869707172737475767778798081828384858687888990919293959496979899100101San Miguel (CSO index 1 - 733)undated102103104105106107108109110Sorata (CSO index 1 - 733)undated111112113114115116117118119120121122123124125126127128129130131132133134135136137138139140141142143144145146147148149150151152Villa Abecia (CSO index 1 - 733)undated153154155156157158159160161162163164165166167168169170171172173174175176177178Series IV. Epidemiological Research Records
Scope and Contents
The materials in this series relate to the epidemiological study conducted between 1964 - 1967. They have been organized into 11 subseries that document the various research activies.
Please note that Subseries G-K, which are organized by community, may contain overlapping, combined data. Subseries A. Blood Examination Laboratory Processing Records
Scope and Contents
This subseries consists of blood examination laboratory processing records. The material in this series was organized in manuscript form by Dr. Franz Ressel, head of epidemiological laboratory procedures in Bolivia. The test results were indexed by Member of the Household Number.Laboratory records1964-19651791-4Subseries B. Blood Samples: Blood Typing Cards
Scope and Contents
Subseries B consists of 2,192 blood typing cards placed in archival polypropylene binders. The cards in this series, housed to minimize movement and moisture retention, were used for blood typing and indexed by the Member of the Household Number.Compi 1-1 to 64-1undated180Compi 64-2 to 98-5 undated181Compi 99-1 to 160-1undated182Coroico 1-1 to 66-1undated183Coroico 66-2 to 133-2undated184Coroico 134-1 to 197-2undated185Coroico 197-3 to 253-1undated186Coroico 253-2 to 270-12undated187Reyes 1-1 to 40-2undated188Reyes 41-1 to 83-1undated189Reyes 83-3 to 127-3undated190Reyes 127-4 to 174-1undated191Reyes 175-1 to 211-1undated192San Miguel 1-1 to 80-1undated193San Miguel 81-1 to 177-2undated194Sorata 2-1 to 62-2undated195Sorata 63-1 to 116-4undated196Sorata 116-5 to 170-1undated197Sorata 170-2 to 177-2undated198Subseries C. Health Questionnaire / Cedula de Salud1964-1965
Scope and Contents
This subseries consists of 1,791 Health Questionnaires (cedulas de salud), organized by community. The Questionnaires were used as a preliminary census that documented the size of households and health conditions of family members. The Questionnaires contain the Community Household Number, written above the page numbers, and the name of the head of household, which may also appear in the existing Biographical Index Cards.Cedula de Salud: Compi 1964-19651991-3Cedula de Salud: Coroico1964-19651994-7Cedula de Salud: Reyes1964-19651998-10Cedula de Salud: Sorata1964-196519911-14Cedula de Salud: Cruz Loma196519915Cedula de Salud: Mururata196519916-17Cedula de Salud: Bolivar Cruzani196519918-19Subseries D. Epidemiological Studies in Bolivia -- Final Report
Scope and Contents

Household Administrative Cards
Scope and Contents
This subseries consists of 703 cards in compound form that includes Household Sanitation information (Subseries H described below). The form includes the Community Household Number, which indexes the epidemiological study documents, and the name of the head of household, which may be included in the Biographical Index.Compi1964-19652051-633541-743551-12Reyes1964-19652061-6035513-563561-703571-31San Miguel1964-19652071-11435732-733581-20Villa Abecia1964-19652081-5635821-603591-54Subseries I. Investigation of Infant Feeding Habits (100)
Scope and Contents
This subseries consists of 100 forms comprising a survey of infant feeding habits in Sorata. The forms include the name of the individual being studied and may also appear in the Biographical Index.Sorata (100)undated209Subseries J. Laboratory Results/ Pruebas de Laboratorio
Scope and Contents
This subseries consists of 5,534 records representating the data collected from 1,186 households in the six study communities, and the schoolchildren of Compi, Coroico, Reyes, LaPaz and Penas. The data is indexed by the Member of the Household Number.Coroico1964-19652101-933601-853621-723631-8Sorata1964-19652091-7735955-623611-91La Paz1964-19653639-12Peas1964-19652111-7Coroico School1964-19652121-5Reyes School1964-19652126-8Compi School1964-19652129-10Series V. Ethnographic Research Records
Scope and Contents note
The materials in this series relate to the ethnographic study undertaken between 1964 and 1967. The final report was published in 1969 as Changing Rural Bolivia. The report was republished in 1971 by Oxford University Press as Changing Rural Society. The materials have been divided into five subseries.Subseries A. Household Structure Diagram/Bosquejo de Casa
Scope and Contents
This subseries consists of 122 forms arranged by the name of the head of household. These documents are stored with the Household Administrative Card-Household Sanitation, Tuberculin Surveys, and Laboratory Results in the Epidemiological Research Material. The Household Structure Diagram was used to register information regarding kinship.Subseries B."Changing Rural Society"
Scope and Contents note
This subseries contains the printed edition, the offset master copy, and preparatory material related to the final report, published as "Changing Rural Bolivia."Changing Rural Bolivia -- Drafts and Correspondence1964-19892131-63472-143641-12Subseries C. Community Census/ Censo de la Comunidad
Scope and Contents
This subseries consists of 161 census forms. This census, undertaken in San Miguel and Sorata, includes the names of the people interviewed, which may also be referenced in the Biographical Index. The census material also includes information about family members, language, education and status in the community.Subseries D. Community Study Outline (CSO)/ Bosquejo para el estudio de las Communidades
Scope and Contents
This subseries consists of the Community Study Outline (CSO)/Bosquejo para el estudio de las communidades. The CSO is an outline that was used to standardize and index the information recorded in the field notes generated by each anthropologist. The one exception is Compi, where the anthropologists were already present in the community conducting their own research. For Compi, only Biographical Index and Member of Household Number designations exist. These forms document geographic environment, population demographics, history and development, institutional systems, the sociopolitical system, community and private health, and the Peace Corps program.Community Study Outline19643471Subseries E. Field Notes / Notas de Campo
Scope and Contents
This subseries consists of 14,000 pages and 30 bound volumes of field notes, organized by community and fieldworker. The field notes were processed by a team of data coders and analysts, who produced the CSO Indexed Field Notes Cards and the Biographical Index.
Each fieldworker is identified by his or her initials. A list of fieldworkers by community may be found below.

Scope and Contents note
The materials in this series have been divided into two subseries.Subseries A. Attitudinal Questionnaire / Cedula de Creencias
Scope and Contents
Subseries A contains 229 Attitudinal Questionnaires/Cedulas de Creencias. These questionnaires have been organized by community and include the names of persons who were interviewed. These names may also appear in the Biographical Index.Coroico19652671-202697-14Reyes19652681-103651-5Sorata19662691-6Subseries B. Household Social Survey / Encuesta Sobre la Comunidad
Scope and Contents
Subseries B contains 1,094 Household Social Surveys/Encuestas sobre la Communidad. These surveys have not been fully analyzed or indexed with other materials in the collection. Some materials were processed and analyzed by Jonathan L. Kelley and Herbert S. Unpublished Manuscripts
Scope and Contents note
The materials in this series have been arranged alphabetically by author's name. This series has been organized into two subseries.Subseries A. Student Papers
Scope and Content
The materials in this subseries consist of student papers prepared by students from Columbia University and the University of Kentucky. Students developed these papers during summer fieldwork studies conducted by by Dr. Lambros Comitas, Assistant Director of the Research Institute for the Study of Man.
Conditions Governing Access

Community and Regional Maps
Scope and Contents note
This series consists of 15 maps, arranged chronologically. Most of the maps in this series were hand drawn and provide details of the communities being studied. The maps were also used for planting purposes and for building.Plano General De La Comunidad "Tauca" Provinicia Omasuyos Canton Stgo De HuataFeb 1957NA1Plano General De La Comunidad "Tauca" Provinicia Omasuyos Canton Stgo De HuataFeb 1957NA2Plano Parcelario y Replanteo de La Propiedad, CompiApr 1958NA3Plano Parcelario y Replanteo de La C omunidad CapilayaundatedNA4Plano Parcial De La Hacienda "Compi"undatedNA5Plano Parcial De La Hacienda "Compi"Aug 1964NA6Plano Parcelario De "Compi" AmasiOct 1965?NA7Plano Parcelario De "Compi"undatedNA8Plano Parcelario De CapilayaundatedNA9Plano Parcelario De CapilayaundatedNA10Plano General De SorataundatedNA11Map of Communidad LlamacachiundatedNA12Map of LlamachiundatedNA13Map of Villa AbeciaundatedNA14Map of CoroicoundatedNA15Series XII. Photographs
Scope and Contents note
This series consists of black-and-white and color photos of varying sizes and contact sheets in 2 photo albums. The pictures depict urban and rural landscapes, indigenous costumes, celebrations and festivals, musicians, market scenes, religious ceremonies, population and interaction between the indigenous population and members of the RISM epidemiology team. Among those credited with taking the photos are Kay Barnes and Victor Novick in Villa Abecia, William McEwen in Sorota, Herbert Klein in San Miguel, K. Barnes and D.B. Heath in Coroico, and Victor Novick in Reyes. Dr. Lambros Comitas provided general photo coverage. A number of photographs were contributed by Dr. Vera D. Rubin.Villa Abecia, Sorota, San Miguel, Coroico, Reyesundated310Studyman1964-1968311Series XIII. Miscellaneous Papers
Scope and Contents note
This series consists of 0.5 linear feet, arranged chronologically. This series contains articles, tables, charts and notes that relate to the Project's research goals. Some material is duplicated in Series I. Scope and Contents
Partly as a result of the RISM Bolivia Project (1964-1967), the United States Office of Education in 1968 and 1969 sponsored a study of rural education in Argentina, Bolivia, and Jamaica. The principal investigator of this study was Lambros Comitas, then Professor of Anthropology and Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, and Associate Director of the Research Institute for the Study of Man.
The Bolivia CV Recordings, an integral part of this comparative study, were taped by Lambros Comitas in 1969 using a Sony Videocorder and CV reel-to-reel videotape for helican scan video recorders.16 mm film -- unlabeledcuid272undated314116 mm film -- "Fable test" (Copy 1)cuid273undated3142Compi School, Bolivia A & B [Master]cuid27419693143
